Grok's API is currently limited to information up to the **end of 2024**. Claude's Sonnet 4.5 has access to up-to-date information, but is considerably more expensive per output (nearly $1 per ticker). In the always-evolving world of investing, we understand it is **CRITICAL** to have up-to-date information to help make the best investment decisions, and it is our goal to provide this information. But considering there are thousands of companies that we would ideally be updating monthly, as well as future goals of also providing quick and digestible summaries and insights for newly released earnings and conference calls, breaking news, FED speeches, etc, this quickly becomes very costly.

For this reason, please consider **subscribing to our Patreon** or donating to enable QuickTick AI to provide as much value and up-to-date insight as possible to **allow you to make the most informed investment decisions with a level of efficiency not possible even a few years ago.** 100% of the funds will go straight to purchasing more API credits to continue expanding our high quality, up-to-date analysis for more and more companies, and further then into our future value-generating plans. Thanks! - QuickTick AI

# Advance Auto Parts, Inc. (AAP) Sell-Side Analysis Report

**Current Stock Metrics (as of October 11, 2024, sourced from Yahoo Finance and Nasdaq):**
- Latest Closing Price: $39.13
- Market Capitalization: $2.34 billion
- 52-Week Range: $21.10 - $71.62
- Trailing P/E: N/A (negative earnings)
- Forward P/E: 11.24
- Dividend Yield: 0.00% (suspended)

## Company Overview
Advance Auto Parts, Inc. (AAP) is one of the largest automotive aftermarket parts retailers in North America, serving both do-it-yourself (DIY) and do-it-for-me (DIFM or professional) customers. Founded in 1932 and headquartered in Raleigh, North Carolina, the company operates approximately 4,800 stores across the U.S., Canada, Puerto Rico, and Mexico under the Advance Auto Parts, CARQUEST, and Worldpac brands. AAP provides a wide range of products including batteries, brakes, chassis parts, climate control, engine components, filters, lighting, oil and lubricants, power sports, radiators, starters, alternators, and wiper blades. It also offers accessories and performance parts through its Advance Same Day service for same-day delivery to professionals. In fiscal 2023, AAP generated $11.2 billion in revenue, with roughly 55% from professional customers and 45% from DIY. The company benefits from an aging U.S. vehicle fleet (average age ~12.5 years), driving demand for aftermarket repairs over new vehicle purchases. AAP differentiates via its extensive store network, vendor-managed inventory (VMI) partnerships, and digital tools like the AdvancePro app for pros. However, it faces intensifying competition and operational challenges, leading to recent sales declines and margin pressures. (187 words)

## Recent Developments
- **Q2 2024 Earnings (August 21, 2024)**: Revenue $2.74 billion (-2.4% YoY); Comparable store sales -2.1%; Diluted EPS $0.22; Adjusted diluted EPS $0.27 (missed consensus $3.30). Gross margin 42.4% (down 390 bps YoY due to tariffs, shrink, and mix). Free cash flow $29 million.
- **Q3 2024 Guidance (August 21, 2024)**: Revenue flat to -2% YoY; Comparable sales flat to -1.5%; Adjusted diluted EPS $1.10-$1.40 (well below prior expectations).
- **Leadership Changes**: CEO Shane O'Kelly stepped down August 16, 2024; COO Ryan Grimsland appointed interim CEO. Board refresh announced September 2024 with new directors.
- **Store Optimization**: Announced closure of ~500 stores by end-2025 (started Q3 2024) to improve profitability; targeting $150M in annual savings.
- **Supply Chain Investments**: Progress on new distribution centers (DCs); 4th DC opened in 2023, 5th in Waco, TX expected Q4 2024.
- **Tariff Impacts**: Q2 earnings highlighted 25% steel/aluminum tariffs adding ~$40M cost pressure in 2024.

## Growth Strategy
- Shift to Professional (Pro) Segment: Targeting 60%+ of sales from Pro by 2025 (currently ~55%); investments in AdvancePro digital platform and VMI expansion.
- Supply Chain Modernization: Building 6 high-velocity DCs (4 operational as of Q2 2024) to cut delivery times 50% and support same-day service for 90% of Pro customers.
- Margin Expansion: Focus on shrink reduction (target <1.5% by 2025), better inventory management, and private-label growth.
- E-commerce and Omnichannel: DIY online sales up 10% YoY in Q2 2024; Pro e-commerce penetration to double.
- Cost Discipline: $500M+ in savings via store closures, SG&A cuts (target 22-23% of sales).

## Company and Sector Headwinds & Tailwinds

| Category     | Headwinds                                                                 | Tailwinds                                                                 |
|--------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Company** | Declining comp sales (7th straight quarter negative as of Q2 2024); Gross margin contraction (supply chain inefficiencies, theft up 30% YoY); High debt ($2.1B net debt); Leadership instability. | Pro segment resilience (comp sales -0.8% in Q2 vs. DIY -3.5%); DC network rollout improving fulfillment (Pro fill rates >95%). |
| **Sector**  | Slowing DIY demand amid high new/used car prices and softening repair rates; Rising theft/shrink industry-wide; Potential auto production recovery reducing aftermarket need. | Aging U.S. fleet (12.5+ years); Stable miles driven; Pro DIFM shift (market growing 4-5% annually); Electric vehicle (EV) aftermarket emerging (~$10B opportunity by 2030). |

## Existing Products/Services
- Core: Parts (brakes 20%, batteries 15%, filters 12% of sales); Accessories; Tools.
- Services: Loaner tool program; Battery charging/install; Pick-up in store (PIS).
- Brands: CARQUEST (Pro-focused), Worldpac (OE parts wholesale), DieHard batteries (licensed).

## New Products/Services/Projects
- **Worldpac Integration**: Full rollout of Worldpac as Pro hub by mid-2025; testing AI-driven parts lookup.
- **EV-Specific Parts**: Launched EV brake kits and charging accessories in Q3 2024.
- **Private Label Expansion**: New "Premium" brake line (Q2 2024 launch, targeting 20% margins).
- **Digital Tools**: AdvancePro 2.0 app update (September 2024) with predictive ordering.

## Market Share Approximations & Forecast
- U.S. Aftermarket Retail: ~9-10% overall (Pro: 15-17%; DIY: 6-7%) per 2023 NPD/IRI data.
- Pro Segment: #3 behind O'Reilly (~25%) and AutoZone (~20%).
- **Forecast**: Slight decline to 8-9% by 2026 due to store closures and comp sales weakness; Pro share stable/flat with investments. Sector growth ~3% CAGR; AAP underperforms peers at 1-2% CAGR.

## Competitor Comparison

| Metric (TTM as of Q2 2024) | AAP          | AutoZone (AZO) | O'Reilly (ORLY) | Genuine Parts (GPC) |
|----------------------------|--------------|----------------|-----------------|---------------------|
| Revenue ($B)              | 11.2        | 18.5           | 16.8            | 23.0                |
| Comp Sales Growth (Q2)    | -2.1%       | +2.8%          | +4.4%           | +1.5%               |
| Gross Margin              | 42.4%       | 54.4%          | 51.5%           | 32.4%               |
| EV/EBITDA                 | 8.2x        | 15.5x          | 14.2x           | 10.1x               |
| Market Share (Pro)        | 16%         | 22%            | 25%             | 18% (wholesale)     |

AAP lags on margins and growth; trades at discount due to execution risks.

## Partnerships, M&A, Clients
- **Partnerships**: Vendor-managed inventory with Worldpac suppliers; DieHard license (Carlisle since 2023); Alliance with Giant Eagle for new store formats (2024 pilot).
- **M&A**: Acquired Worldpac (2019, $1.6B); No major deals since; divestitures like Bumper-to-Bumper (2023).
- **Major Clients**: Pro customers include independent repair shops (80% of Pro sales), fleets (e.g., Pep Boys, national chains); OEM dealers.
- **Potential**: EV service chains (e.g., Electrify America partnerships rumored); Expansion into Mexico Pro market.

## Other Qualitative Measures
- **ESG**: Committed to 25% emissions cut by 2030; 90% recyclable packaging goal.
- **Analyst Sentiment**: Consensus "Hold" (17 Buys, 20 Holds, 2 Sells per Yahoo Finance); Avg PT $51.
- **Risks**: Recession sensitivity (repairs deferrable); China tariffs (30% parts sourced).
- **Opportunities**: Pro loyalty (Net Promoter Score 65+); $1T addressable aftermarket.

## Investment Recommendation
- **Buy Rating**: 4/10 (Weak Hold/Sell tilt). Recent earnings misses, margin erosion, and guidance cuts signal ongoing execution issues despite Pro shift and supply chain fixes. Peers outperforming; stock down 45% YTD.
- **Estimated Fair Value**: $55/share (30% upside). Based on 10x 2025E EV/EBITDA (peer avg 13x adjusted for risks) and 2% revenue CAGR to $11.5B, 45% margins yielding $1.2B EBITDA. DCF assumes 8% WACC, 2.5% terminal growth. Suitable for moderate-risk growth portfolios if Pro turnaround materializes by mid-2025.
